You are correct, and I apologize for the mistake in my previous response. Reynald de Chatillon's infamous act of covering someone with honey and leaving them on a roof was not directed towards Muslim prisoners, but rather the Patriarch of Antioch, Aimery of Limoges.

According to the account given by William of Tyre in his "Deeds Done Beyond the Sea," Reynald de Chatillon captured Aimery during a military campaign against the city of Shaizar in 1111. He then subjected the Patriarch to the humiliating treatment of being covered with honey and left exposed to bees and other insects on the roof of his castle. This act of cruelty was considered a grave offense against the church and was widely condemned.

Reynald's actions towards Aimery were not the only example of his brutal behavior during the Crusades, and he was known for his repeated attacks against Muslims, as well as Christians who he deemed to be his enemies. His actions ultimately led to his downfall when he was captured by Saladin's forces and executed in 1187.
